title: Effect of P on collision frequency

content.question: The gas-phase reaction <math alttext="A 2 gas plus B 2 gas react to produce 2 A B gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>2</mtext></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>â†’</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>AB</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to occur in a single step. Two experiments were done at the same temperature inside rigid containers. The initial partial pressures of <math alttext="A 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>2</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> used in experiment 1 were twice the initial pressures used in experiment 2. Which statement provides the best comparison of the initial rate of formation of <math alttext="A B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in experiments 1 and 2 ?

choices.label: The initial rate of formation of <math alttext="A B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>AB</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is the same in both experiments because they were done at the same temperature and the frequency and energy of the collisions between <math alttext="A 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> would have been about the same.

The initial rate of formation of <math alttext="A B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is slower in experiment 1 than in with experiment 2 because at the same temperature, a higher pressure would reduce the volume available for <math alttext="A 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules to achieve the proper orientation for a successful collision.

The initial rate of formation of <math alttext="A B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is faster in experiment 1 than in experiment 2 because at a higher pressure the collisions between <math alttext="A 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules would have been more frequent, increasing the probability of a successful collision.

The initial rate of formation of <math alttext="A B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>AB</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is faster in experiment 1 than in experiment 2 because at a higher pressure a larger fraction of the <math alttext="A 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules would have the minimum energy required to overcome the activation energy barrier.

content.answer: The initial rate of formation of <math alttext="A B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is faster in experiment 1 than in experiment 2 because at a higher pressure the collisions between <math alttext="A 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules would have been more frequent, increasing the probability of a successful collision.

skill.text: 6.E: Provide reasoning to justify a claim using connections between particulate and macroscopic scales or levels.
